Blog.post: Today I am faced with a moral dilemma that most people would ignore. In today's society, there seems to be an ever-expanding region between what is right and wrong. The gray areas are expanding, and soon will cover the complete spectrum of morality. I feel that celebrities are in no position to force their views and followers to vote for a certain political party. Yesterday I received an e-mail from one of my favorite artists, the urlLink Dave Matthews Band , announcing that the band would be playing at a John Kerry benefit at Radio City Music Hall in New York City. If you have been reading my previous posts, you are aware that I am an avid conservative supporter, and a firm supporter of urlLink President George W. Bush . Hence, my dilemma arises. What should I do? Is it wrong to support someone who leads others in the opposite direction? Hopefully if you are reading this, you understand my concern. What gives a celebrity any more political expertise than the common working man?

I have been completely turned off to the liberal media lately. It seems that everywhere you turn, there is someone blasting the conservative government leaders. The majority of news sources are bent on getting the Bush administration out of the White House. Here's my question. If Bush had known ahead of time about the severity of the 9/11 attacks, and he went in and completely leveled the mountains of Afghanistan, would how would the media react? Why is it that we blame the government for being both proactive and inactive ? I was watching Michael Moore on urlLink The Late Show with David Letterman and I was blown away at the amount of rank propaganda that was spewing out of his mouth. Even someone as liberal as Dave Letterman was shocked at the view of Moore's "documentary" on Bush's response to the 9/11 attacks. urlLink Bill O'Reilly says it best in his weekly news column, " urlLink The Evolution of Michael Moore ," Any skilled filmmaker, and Moore is that, could fashion a movie making any American look like a pinhead. That's easy to do. Just get a bunch of video, some people who hate the guy, some factoids that may or may not be true, heat it up with sardonic rhetoric and serve. Presto, Fahrenheit 9/11. I do not understand how Moore can be considered a documentary film-maker. In order to be categorized as a documentary, a film "must present facts objectively without editorializing or inserting fictional matter." Mr. Moore has publicly admitted to presenting information in a bias manner, and in doing so he has taken all creditablity away from his liberal film." I was listening to the radio this morning, and something hit me that was quite interesting. Someone mentioned on the radio that it is impossible to live the perfect life. The idea of having the ideal parents, going to the right school, meeting the right mate, getting the right job, finding the right retirement... is all wishful thinking. Is this true? Is life just a game of chance? I am so undeserving of my current situation. I have the greatest urlLink wife in the world, and each day I love her more. It doesn't get any better than my parents and sister, and I am healthy for the most part. All of the important aspects of my life are covered, and none of it can be attributed to anything I have done. The more I think about it, the less reason I have to complain about anything. So the moral is, don't take anything for granted. We never know what tomorrow holds. Love like you've never loved before, and have as much fun as you can! What's holding you back?

What if God Shuffled By? I recently had the opportunity to have lunch with a friend from several years ago. It isn't that he hasn't been around, but life has just consumed all of our time - his time is now taken up by a wife and two children, and mine by my urlLink wonderful wife and my job. While at lunch, I found that we still had a lot in common. We met in church, and still go to the same church. We had a very interesting discussion about what it means to be a Christian, and what God really expects out of us as human beings. I feel that the church in general has such a distorted view of what God wants to do in and around us. I feel that a lot of the time people try to "do Christian things" - such as go to church, not drink, not smoke, do the do's, don't do the don't's... I am so tired of people telling you how to live, how to do things... God isn't about that. Jesus never prayed for us to be separated from the world... In fact, he did quite the opposite. He prayed for us to be in the world. He wanted us to spend time with the dirtiest, smelliest people on the face of the earth. I was surprised to see that I wasn't the only person who had the same theological view. I have thought for so long that I had some distorted view of reality, but on the contrary... I am beginning to see that maybe my view isn't so wrong after all.
